---
title: Data Binding Using data-* Attributes
published: 2012-05-23
---

<p>Custom <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en/DOM/element.dataset" target="_blank"><code>data-*</code> attributes</a> in HTML5 are pretty rad. They&rsquo;re especially handy for stashing small amounts of data and retaining minimal state on the DOM. Turns out, they can also be used for one-way data binding!</p>

<p>I&rsquo;ve been using a nifty trick in recent projects that I thought would be worth sharing. The technique is to use a data attribute to store values (i.e. the data model) and <code>:before</code>/<code>:after</code> pseudo elements to render the values as generated content (i.e. the view). I call it <strong>&ldquo;poor man&rsquo;s data binding&rdquo;</strong> because it&rsquo;s not true data binding in the traditional sense, but the semantics are similar. Count it!</p>

<p>Here we go:</p>

<pre><code>&lt;style&gt;
  input {
    vertical-align: middle;
    margin: 2em;
    font-size: 14px;
    height: 20px;
  }
  input::after {
    content: attr(data-value) '/' attr(max);
    position: relative;
    left: 135px;
    top: -20px;
  }
&lt;/style&gt;
&lt;input type="range" min="0" max="100" value="25"&gt;
&lt;script&gt;
  var input = document.querySelector('input');

  input.dataset.value = input.value; // Set an initial value.

  input.addEventListener('change', function(e) {
    this.dataset.value = this.value;
  });
&lt;/script&gt;
</code></pre>

<p><a href="http://jsbin.com/iwitod/4/edit#html,live" target="_blank"><strong>TRY IT</strong></a></p>

<p>Notice the <code>25/100</code> updates as you move the slider, but the <code>&lt;input&gt;</code> is the only markup on the page.</p>

<p>The magic line is the <code>content: attr(data-value) '/' attr(max)</code>. It uses CSS <code>attr()</code> to pull out the <code>data-value</code> and <code>max</code> attributes; both set using markup on the <code>&lt;input&gt;</code>. As those values change, the generated content is automatically updated. Sick data binding bro.</p>

<p>Really the only benefit of this technique is that we&rsquo;re not including extraneous markup.</p>

<p>Last but not least, here&rsquo;s a more complex example that uses CSS transitions to change the height of a <code>div</code> container when clicked. As the height changes, <code>requestAnimationFrame()</code> updates the <code>data-height</code> of the <code>div</code> and the pseudo element picks that up.</p>

<figure style="text-align: center;border:1px solid #ccc;padding: 0.5em;">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,"/>
<figcaption><a href="http://jsbin.com/zekohaxenu" target="_blank">TRY IT</a></figcaption></figure><p>I&rsquo;m sure if HTML was conceived in the age of web apps, we&rsquo;d have proper DOM/JS data binding by now. Fortunately, initiatives like <a href="http://code.google.com/p/mdv/" target="_blank">MDV</a> and <a href="http://dvcs.w3.org/hg/webcomponents/raw-file/tip/explainer/index.html" target="_blank">Web Components</a> are on their way. One day this stuff will be a reality and native to HTML!</p>

<p><em><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_binding" target="_blank">Data binding</a> is a technique for automatically synchronizing data between two sources. On the web, data binding typically manifests itself as updating DOM (UI) in response to events: XHRs, user input, or other business logic doing its thing. Take the canonical todo list for example. When I mark an item as done, the completed count increments. When it&rsquo;s unchecked, the count decrements. That&rsquo;s data binding!</em></p>

<p><em>If you want true two-way data binding, checkout one of the popular <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model%E2%80%93view%E2%80%93controller" target="_blank">MVC</a> frameworks like <a href="http://angularjs.org/" target="_blank">Angular</a>, <a href="http://knockoutjs.com/" target="_blank">Knockout</a>, or <a href="http://emberjs.org" target="_blank">Ember</a>.</em></p>
